page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content:
{PLANNING THE PARK.} LORD BATHURST PLANNED THE PARK IN THE STYLE OF VERSAILLES AND COMPIEGNE. A SERIES OF AVENUES MET IN A 'ROND POINT' COMMANDING FINE VIEWS OF THE COUNTRYSIDE. LORD BATHURST ADAPTED THIS PLAN TO A DESIGN MORE TYPICAL OF THE ENGLISH COUNTRYSIDE THAN THE FORMAL FRENCH GARDEN. TEN THOUSAND ACRES WERE ADDED TO THE ESTATE. MANY EXISTING TREES WERE CUT DOWN AND THE CONTOURS OF THE LAND MOULDED TO GIVE THE APPEARANCE OF HEIGHT AND DEPTH. THE RESULT IS UNIQUE AND IS SAID TO BE {ONE OF THE FINEST EXAMPLES OF GEORGIAN {LANDSCAPE-GARDEN. }
THE WORK WAS BEGUN IN 1714 AND THE SCENE HAS CHANGED BUT LITTLE SINCE THAT TIME.
